title: Were there any WWII bomber tail gunner aces? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t know of any tail gunner aces but the guy I am about to tell you a story of has, IMHO a story worth telling. (Sorry if this story offends the puritans amongst us who will complain that I am not addressing the precise question, but a tail gunner was brought up and this tail gunner’s story deserves to be told. So, to those who complain – get over it and move on with your lives. On the night of 24 March 1944, 21-year-old Flight Sergeant Nicholas Alkemade was a tail gunner and one of seven crew members in a Royal Air Force Avro Lancaster bomber returning from a bombing raid on Berlin. His aircraft was attacked by a German night fighter, caught fire and began to spiral out of control. Because his parachute had gone up in flames, it was unserviceable. Alkemade decided to jump from the aircraft without it, preferring to die by impact rather than burn to death. He fell 18,000 feet to the ground below. His fall was broken by pine trees and a soft snow cover on the ground. He suffered only a sprained leg. The Lancaster crashed in flames, killing the pilot and three other crew members. Alkemade was subsequently captured and interviewed by the Gestapo, who were initially suspicious of his claim to have fallen without a parachute. But when the wreckage of the aircraft was found and examined his captors reportedly gave him a certificate testifying to the fact. He was a celebrated POW, before being repatriated in May 1945. Now there is one bad-ass tail gunner!

During WW2 the following air gunners became aces while manning tail turrets on Bomber Aircraft. British Commonwealth: Wallace McIntosh, 207 Squadron RAF (Lancaster): 8 victoriesC. Sutherland, 207 Squadron RAF (Lancaster): 7 victories?. Bradford, 57 Squadron RAF (Lancaster): 6 victories USA: S/SGT Michael Arooth, 527 Bomb Squadron 379 Bomb Group 8 Air Force USAAF (B-17): 17 victoriesS/SGT Donald Crossley, 95 Bomb Group 8 Air Force USAAF (B-17): 12 victories S/SGT John B Quinlan, 324 Bomb Squadron 91 Bomb Group 8 & 20 Air Forces USAAF (B-17 “Memphis Belle”): 5 victories, (B-29): 3 victories. There were other gunners who qualified as aces from other positions, mostly dorsal turrets, or in other types of aircraft. The top scoring RAF gunners manned turrets on BP Defiant fighters. For a complete list, use this link: The forgotten ACES: Air gunner ACES of WWII (image heavy) I have not found any figures for Axis gunners.
